misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays “auto-stay-in-sync” after sorting one array
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that sorting the `scores` array will also implicitly rearrange the `names` array to keep each name matched with its corresponding score, so that `names[n-1]` will be the name of the student with the highest score after `Arrays.sort(scores)`.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, `Arrays.sort(scores)` only reorders the elements inside the `scores` array. It does not know anything about the `names` array, and Java will not automatically apply the same swaps to a separate array. Parallel arrays must be sorted together (swap both arrays when comparing/swapping), or you must sort indices / create objects (e.g., a `Student` class) and sort those. As written, after sorting, `scores[n-1]` is the maximum score, but `names[n-1]` is merely the last-entered name, so the pairing is broken.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output: prints the maximum score but may print the wrong student name (often the last name entered).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that when they sort the scores array, the names array will automatically rearrange itself in parallel, maintaining the correspondence between names and scores at each index position.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, Arrays.sort() only sorts the array it is called on. Sorting the scores array does not automatically sort the names array. The indices that paired names with scores before sorting no longer correspond after sorting only one array. The student's mental model treats parallel arrays as a single unified data structure that moves together, when in reality they are independent arrays.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - the program will print the name at index n-1 from the unsorted names array paired with the highest score from the sorted scores array, producing incorrect name-score combinations. For example, with the sample input, it would output 'Charlie (92)' instead of 'Bob (92)'.

evidence.code_snippet:
String topName = names[n - 1];
        int topScore = scores[n - 1];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because the names and scores were entered into the same index positions (i) in two different arrays, the computer recognizes a permanent logical link between them. Consequently, the student expects that if one array is rearranged (e.g., sorted), the corresponding elements in the 'parallel' array will automatically follow their original partners to their new indices.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: The student does not realize that parallel arrays are independent structures in memory with no intrinsic connection. The java.util.Arrays.sort() method only manipulates the internal order of the specific array passed to it (scores). It has no awareness of the names array, leading to a 'desynchronization' where the highest score no longer aligns with the correct name.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Logic error resulting in incorrect output. The program will print the name that was entered last into the input buffer, regardless of whether that student actually earned the highest score.

misconceptions.inferred_category_name: Parallel arrays are “magically linked” during sorting
misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because `names[i]` corresponds to `scores[i]` before sorting, sorting the `scores` array will keep (or automatically update) the pairing so the last name will still belong to the highest score after the sort.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In Java, arrays are independent data structures. `Arrays.sort(scores)` only reorders the elements inside the `scores` array; it does not (and cannot) automatically reorder a separate `names` array to match. After sorting `scores`, the index positions no longer represent the original name–score pairings unless you also move `names` in the same way (or you sort objects/pairs together).
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output (prints the correct highest score but often the wrong student name, because the name and score arrays become misaligned).

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that after sorting one array (scores), the index correspondence between the parallel arrays is automatically preserved. They assume that using the same index position to access both arrays after sorting will still retrieve logically paired data.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In reality, sorting one array reorders only that array. The other parallel array (names) remains in its original order. The index synchronization that existed before sorting is broken. To maintain correspondence, both arrays must be reordered together using the same swap operations, which the code does not do.
misconceptions.error_manifestation: Wrong output - the program prints 'Top student: Charlie (92)' instead of 'Top student: Bob (92)'. After sorting scores to [78, 85, 92], the name 'Charlie' at index 2 no longer corresponds to the score 92 at index 2.

evidence.code_snippet:
String topName = names[n - 1];
        int topScore = scores[n - 1];

misconceptions.student_thought_process: The student believes that because two arrays are logically related (parallel), the computer maintains this link automatically during operations. Specifically, they believe that sorting the 'scores' array will implicitly cause the 'names' array to be reordered in the same way to preserve the association between a student and their score.
misconceptions.conceptual_gap: In the Java execution model, arrays are independent objects in memory. The 'Arrays.sort()' method only receives a reference to the 'scores' array and has no knowledge of, or access to, the 'names' array. To maintain parallel relationships during a sort, the programmer must implement a manual sorting algorithm (like Bubble Sort) that swaps elements in both arrays simultaneously, or use an object-oriented approach.
